entry.title: Rubber vs. Plastic: When to Choose Rubber for Your Parts

link.title: Rubber vs. Plastic: When to Choose Rubber for Your Parts

entry.content:
When designing a new product, one of the first decisions engineers face is choosing between rubber and plastic. Both materials can be molded into complex shapes, both are cost-effective, and both can be tailored to a wide range of applications.

But in certain situations — especially when flexibility, sealing, or vibration resistance are critical — rubber is the clear winner. In this post, we’ll compare rubber and plastic, explore their advantages and limitations, and explain when choosing rubber makes the most sense.

The Key Differences Between Rubber and Plastic

At a basic level, rubber is elastic while plastic is rigid. That single difference affects almost every aspect of performance.

Property Rubber Plastic
Flexibility Highly elastic and returns to original shape Typically rigid, limited flexibility
Sealing Ability Excellent — conforms to surfaces Poor — relies on tight tolerances
Temperature Range Performs well in heat and cold Can become brittle or deform
Vibration Damping Absorbs shock and vibration Transmits vibration
Chemical Resistance Depends on compound Depends on resin type
Cost Slightly higher per part Often lower in high-volume runs

The right choice depends on how your part needs to function under real-world conditions.

When to Choose Rubber Over Plastic

Rubber has unique properties that make it ideal for applications requiring movement, sealing, or energy absorption. Here are a few examples:

1. When You Need Flexibility

Rubber stretches and compresses without breaking. This makes it perfect for seals, gaskets, hoses, and vibration mounts — parts that need to flex repeatedly or maintain contact under pressure.

2. When You Need Sealing or Isolation

Rubber conforms to irregular surfaces and maintains an airtight or watertight seal. That’s why it’s used in valves, o-rings, and housing gaskets where even the smallest leak can cause major issues.

3. When You Need Vibration Damping

Rubber naturally absorbs energy, reducing noise and vibration in machinery, vehicles, and equipment. Plastic parts, by contrast, tend to transmit vibration and wear out faster in dynamic environments.

4. When You Need Temperature or Chemical Resistance

Specialized rubber compounds (like EPDM, Nitrile, or Viton) can withstand extreme heat, cold, and chemical exposure that would quickly degrade most plastics.

5. When You Need a Softer Touch

Rubber is ideal for grips, handles, and bumpers, offering a soft-touch feel and improved ergonomics that plastic can’t replicate.

When Plastic May Be a Better Option

In some cases, plastic is still the right choice — particularly when you need:

  • High structural rigidity
  • Very tight dimensional tolerances
  • Transparent or decorative parts
  • Extreme wear resistance under dry conditions

Plastics are also better for ultra-high-volume production when cost per part is the primary concern.

Hybrid Designs — The Best of Both Worlds

Some of the most effective designs combine rubber and plastic (or metal) through overmolding. This process creates a strong, durable part with a rigid core and a soft, functional exterior.

For example:

  • A plastic handle with a rubber grip
  • A metal insert with a rubber vibration isolator

This hybrid approach delivers strength where needed and flexibility where it matters most.

How Primo Rubber Co. Can Help

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom rubber injection molding and rubber-to-metal bonding, helping customers design parts that perform better and last longer.

Our U.S.-based team can:

  • Help you determine if rubber is the right choice for you
  • Recommend the best rubber compound for your application
  • Produce high-quality, consistent parts with tight tolerances

Whether you’re replacing a rigid plastic part that’s been failing or developing a new design from scratch, we can guide you through every step.

Built for Performance. Built in the USA.

Choosing the right material is one of the most important design decisions you’ll make. With Primo Rubber Co., you’re not just getting parts — you’re getting decades of experience, technical expertise, and a partner committed to your success.

Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to discuss your project and find out how the right rubber solution can make your parts stronger, longer-lasting, and more reliable.
entry.summary: Explore the differences between rubber and plastic, and learn when rubber is the better choice for your custom molded components.

entry.title: Understanding Durometer — How Rubber Hardness Affects Performance

link.title: Understanding Durometer — How Rubber Hardness Affects Performance

entry.content:
When designing custom rubber parts, durometer is one of the most important — and often overlooked — properties to get right. The durometer of a rubber compound determines how soft or hard it feels, how it compresses, and how it performs under load.

Choosing the wrong hardness can lead to seal failures, poor vibration control, or parts that simply don’t fit as intended. In this post, we’ll break down what durometer means, how it’s measured, and how it affects the performance of your rubber components.

What Is Durometer?

Durometer is a measure of a material’s hardness — specifically, its resistance to indentation. It’s usually measured on the Shore hardness scale, which was developed to evaluate the hardness of elastomers and plastics.

For most rubber materials, the Shore A scale is used. This scale ranges from:

  • 0 Shore A — extremely soft and flexible (like a rubber band)
  • 100 Shore A — very hard and rigid (similar to a shopping cart wheel)

The measurement is taken using a durometer gauge, which presses a small indenter into the material’s surface under a standardized force. The depth of indentation determines the hardness reading.

Why Durometer Matters

Rubber hardness plays a direct role in how a part performs under pressure, heat, and motion. A seal that’s too soft may compress too much and leak; one that’s too hard may fail to conform to its mating surface.

Here’s how durometer impacts key performance areas:

Property Soft Rubber (Lower Durometer) Hard Rubber (Higher Durometer)
Compression & Flexibility More flexible and easily deformed Stiffer and resists compression
Vibration Damping Better energy absorption Lower damping capacity
Abrasion Resistance Lower Higher
Tensile Strength Moderate Generally higher
Sealing Ability Excellent for uneven surfaces Best for smooth, tight tolerances

In short: soft rubbers seal better, while harder rubbers last longer under load.

Typical Durometer Ranges by Material

Each rubber material has its own hardness range and can be formulated to meet specific performance goals:

Material Typical Durometer Range (Shore A) Common Applications
Silicone 30–80 Seals, gaskets, medical devices
EPDM 40–90 Outdoor seals, automotive weatherstripping
Nitrile (Buna-N) 40–90 Oil-resistant gaskets, hydraulic seals
Neoprene 30–90 Shock mounts, industrial seals
FKM (Viton) 60–95 High-temperature chemical-resistant seals

Selecting the right hardness is a balancing act between flexibility, strength, and durability.

Design Considerations for Rubber Hardness

When specifying durometer for your part, consider:

  1. Compression Set Resistance — A harder compound may resist deformation over time, but can also increase sealing pressure.
  2. Operating Environment — Heat, chemicals, and exposure to oil can change a material’s hardness over its lifespan.
  3. Mating Surface — Softer rubber is ideal when sealing against rough or uneven surfaces.
  4. Part Geometry — Thicker sections can feel stiffer even at the same durometer rating, while thinner walls may require harder materials to prevent collapse.

Working with an experienced manufacturer can help you dial in the right hardness for your exact use case.

Choosing the Right Partner

Selecting the correct durometer isn’t just about picking a number — it’s about understanding how your part will perform in the real world. The best results come from collaboration between designers, engineers, and manufacturers.

How Primo Rubber Co. Can Help

At Primo Rubber Co., we help customers optimize durometer selection for performance, cost, and manufacturability. Our team has extensive experience molding rubber parts across a full range of hardness levels and materials — from soft silicone gaskets to rigid, high-strength bushings.

If you’re designing a new product or troubleshooting an existing one, we can help you choose and mold the right rubber compound for your needs.

Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn what durometer means, how rubber hardness is measured, and how to choose the right durometer for your molded rubber parts.

entry.title: How Rubber Is Bonded to Metal

link.title: How Rubber Is Bonded to Metal

entry.content:
Rubber-to-metal bonding is a critical process in manufacturing durable components used in everything from automotive mounts to industrial vibration isolators. It combines the flexibility and sealing power of rubber with the strength and stability of metal — creating parts that can handle stress, temperature changes, and harsh environments.

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in creating strong, reliable rubber-to-metal bonds that perform consistently and stand the test of time. Here’s how the process works — and how the right manufacturing partner makes all the difference.

The Basics of Rubber-to-Metal Bonding

Rubber-to-metal bonding involves chemically and mechanically joining a rubber compound to a metal substrate during the molding process. Unlike simple gluing, the rubber and metal become permanently fused at the molecular level during vulcanization (the curing process).

This creates a composite part where the rubber and metal act as one — ideal for applications that demand vibration isolation, shock absorption, fluid sealing, or structural reinforcement.

Step 1: Preparing the Metal Surface

The foundation of a strong bond starts with proper surface preparation. Any oil, rust, or dirt on the metal can prevent adhesion, so the substrate must be cleaned thoroughly. Common preparation steps include:

  • Degreasing: Removes oils, coolants, or machining residues.
  • Grit blasting: Roughens the surface for better mechanical adhesion.
  • Chemical cleaning or etching: Improves surface energy and consistency.

In some cases, the metal may also be phosphate coated or heat-treated to enhance adhesion and corrosion resistance.

Step 2: Applying the Bonding Agent

Once the surface is prepared, a specialized bonding agent (also called primer or adhesive system) is applied. This adhesive forms the critical bridge between the rubber and metal.

Most rubber-to-metal adhesives are two-coat systems:

  1. Primer layer – adheres to the metal surface.
  2. Topcoat – bonds chemically with the rubber during vulcanization.

The coated metal inserts are then dried or baked to remove solvents and activate the adhesive before molding.

Step 3: Molding and Vulcanization

After adhesive application, the metal inserts are placed into a rubber injection mold or compression mold. Molten or semi-molten rubber is then injected under pressure, filling the cavities and surrounding the metal.

As the rubber cures under heat and pressure, the adhesive forms a chemical bond between the rubber molecules and the metal substrate. The result is a single, integrated component that’s incredibly strong and durable — even under extreme stress or temperature.

Step 4: Inspection and Testing

After molding, bonded parts are carefully inspected for:

  • Bond coverage (complete adhesion over the desired surface)
  • Pull or peel strength (measured through adhesion tests)
  • Surface defects or contamination

For critical applications, such as in automotive or industrial equipment, bonded parts may also undergo environmental testing — including thermal cycling, oil immersion, or vibration testing — to ensure long-term performance.

Common Rubber-to-Metal Applications

You’ll find bonded rubber-to-metal parts in nearly every industry, including:

  • Automotive: engine mounts, suspension bushings, vibration dampers
  • Industrial machinery: isolators, pump mounts, couplings
  • Construction and heavy equipment: seals, shock absorbers, gaskets
  • Aerospace and defense: antivibration mounts, fuel system seals

These parts play an essential role in extending equipment life and improving performance.

How Primo Rubber Co. Can Help

At Primo Rubber Co., we bring years of experience in rubber injection molding and metal bonding technology. Our process ensures:

  • Exceptional adhesion strength using proven bonding agents
  • Precise molding control for consistent quality
  • Broad material compatibility, including nitrile, EPDM, silicone, neoprene, and FKM
  • Domestic production, giving you faster turnaround and easier communication

Whether you need rubber bonded to steel, aluminum, brass, or specialty alloys, we can engineer a solution tailored to your performance and cost requirements.

Partner with a Trusted U.S. Manufacturer

Rubber-to-metal bonding may seem simple, but it takes experience and attention to detail to get right. With Primo Rubber Co., you get more than parts — you get a partner committed to quality, reliability, and long-term performance.

Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to discuss your bonded part needs and discover how we can help you produce durable, high-quality rubber-to-metal components right here in the U.S.
entry.summary: Learn how rubber is bonded to metal through surface prep, adhesives, and molding — and how Primo Rubber Co. produces strong, lasting rubber-to-metal components.

entry.title: How Tooling Design Affects the Quality of Rubber Molded Parts

link.title: How Tooling Design Affects the Quality of Rubber Molded Parts

entry.content:
When it comes to rubber injection molding, the quality of the final part is determined long before the first shot is made — it starts with the tooling design. A well-designed mold ensures consistent dimensions, smooth surface finishes, and efficient production. Poor tooling design, on the other hand, can lead to flash, voids, uneven curing, or premature wear. Understanding how tooling affects part quality is key to achieving reliable, high-performance results.

Precision in Mold Cavities

The mold cavity defines the exact shape of your finished part. Even a tiny dimensional error can create big downstream issues. Tolerances in the thousandths of an inch matter — especially for seals, grommets, or other precision components. Properly machined cavities ensure your parts stay consistent across thousands of molding cycles.

Gate and Runner Design

The way molten rubber enters the mold determines how evenly it flows and cures. Poor gate placement can cause air traps, weld lines, or uneven fill, leading to cosmetic flaws or weak areas. Optimized gate and runner design ensures the rubber reaches every area of the mold evenly, reducing waste and improving cycle time.

Venting and Air Management

Trapped air is one of the most common causes of defects in molded rubber parts. Well-designed venting channels allow gases to escape during injection and curing, preventing burn marks, voids, and incomplete fills. This is especially critical for parts with thin walls or intricate shapes.

Temperature Control

Rubber molding depends on precise heating and curing. Uneven mold temperatures can cause inconsistent hardness, shrinkage, or undercured regions. Smart heating and cooling channels within the mold help maintain stable process conditions — ensuring repeatable, high-quality results.

Material Shrinkage Compensation

Each rubber compound behaves differently during cooling and curing. Tooling must account for material shrinkage rates so that finished parts meet dimensional specs. Experienced mold designers balance these allowances based on the rubber formulation and part geometry.

Durability and Maintenance

Tooling materials and finishes have a direct impact on part quality and production uptime. Hardened steels and surface coatings reduce wear from abrasive compounds and extend mold life. Easy-to-clean vents and replaceable inserts help maintain consistent quality over long production runs.

Partnering With Experts for Reliable Tooling

At Primo Rubber Co., we know that the mold is the heart of the process. Our team collaborates closely with customers from the design stage to ensure every detail — from gate placement to venting — is optimized for performance, consistency, and cost-efficiency. Whether you need precision seals, vibration isolators, or custom gaskets, we make sure our tooling delivers dependable quality with every shot. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn how precision tooling design impacts the quality, consistency, and performance of rubber molded parts. Discover key factors in gating, venting, and temperature control.

entry.title: Oil-Resistant Rubber Materials: What to Use for Automotive or Industrial Seals

link.title: Oil-Resistant Rubber Materials: What to Use for Automotive or Industrial Seals

entry.content:
When designing seals, gaskets, or hoses that come in contact with fuels, lubricants, or hydraulic fluids, oil resistance becomes one of the most important material properties. Not all rubber compounds are created equal — exposure to oils and hydrocarbons can cause swelling, softening, or complete material failure if the wrong compound is used.

In this guide, we’ll cover the best oil-resistant rubber materials, their advantages, and how to choose the right one for your application.

Why Oil Resistance Matters

Oil exposure attacks rubber from the inside out. Petroleum-based fluids can dissolve or displace plasticizers in the compound, leading to:

  • Swelling and loss of shape
  • Reduced tensile strength
  • Surface cracking or tackiness
  • Permanent deformation or leaks

In dynamic seals, these effects cause premature wear and loss of sealing pressure — which can mean downtime, contamination, or system failure. Choosing the right rubber compound helps prevent these costly problems.

Nitrile Rubber (Buna-N)

Nitrile rubber (NBR) is the most widely used oil-resistant material. It performs exceptionally well in contact with petroleum oils, fuels, greases, and many hydraulic fluids.

Advantages:

  • Excellent resistance to oil and fuel
  • Good abrasion and tear resistance
  • Available in a wide hardness range
  • Cost-effective for large production runs

Limitations:

  • Poor resistance to ozone and UV
  • Not ideal for extreme temperatures (typically -30°F to +250°F)

Best For:
Automotive seals, fuel hoses, oil-resistant grommets, and industrial gaskets.

Hydrogenated Nitrile (HNBR)

HNBR is a modified version of Nitrile that improves heat, ozone, and aging resistance while maintaining strong oil resistance.

Advantages:

  • Higher temperature stability (up to 300°F)
  • Excellent resistance to oils and fuels
  • Improved mechanical strength and longevity

Limitations:

  • Higher cost than standard Nitrile
  • Slightly reduced flexibility at low temperatures

Best For:

High-performance automotive seals, oilfield components, and industrial machinery exposed to heat and oil.

Fluoroelastomers (Viton® / FKM)

Viton and other fluoroelastomers (FKM) offer the ultimate resistance to oils, fuels, and aggressive chemicals. They are ideal for extreme environments where both heat and chemical exposure are concerns.

Advantages:

  • Excellent resistance to fuels, oils, and solvents
  • Handles continuous temperatures up to 400°F
  • Exceptional chemical resistance

Limitations:

  • Higher material cost
  • Limited low-temperature flexibility

Best For:

Aerospace seals, high-performance automotive systems, and industrial sealing in harsh chemical environments.

Other Oil-Resistant Options

  • Neoprene: Good for general-purpose oil and fuel resistance, though not as strong as Nitrile or Viton.
  • Polyacrylate (ACM): Used in automotive transmission and engine seals for high-temperature oil resistance.
  • EPDM: Poor oil resistance — best avoided in petroleum-based environments.

Selecting the Right Compound

When choosing an oil-resistant rubber, consider:

  • Temperature range of operation
  • Type of oil or fuel (synthetic, mineral, bio-based, etc.)
  • Pressure and mechanical stress on the part
  • Exposure to ozone, UV, or outdoor conditions

Testing in real-world conditions is always recommended before full production.

Trusted Rubber Solutions from Primo Rubber Co.

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom rubber parts and seals that stand up to the toughest environments. Whether your application demands cost-effective Nitrile or high-performance Viton, our team helps you select and mold the right compound for long-lasting, oil-resistant performance. Partner with us to produce quality rubber components that you can rely on. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn which rubber compounds offer the best oil and fuel resistance for automotive, industrial, and hydraulic sealing applications.

entry.title: How to Improve Durability in Industrial Rubber Seals and Gaskets

link.title: How to Improve Durability in Industrial Rubber Seals and Gaskets

entry.content:
Rubber seals and gaskets are the unsung heroes of industrial systems — keeping fluids contained, machinery protected, and equipment running smoothly. When these components fail, the result can be costly downtime, safety hazards, and even product recalls. That’s why improving the durability of industrial rubber seals and gaskets is one of the smartest investments any manufacturer can make.

At Primo Rubber Co., we’ve seen firsthand how small design or material changes can dramatically extend part life. In this post, we’ll cover the key factors that influence seal and gasket performance — and how to make your components last longer in tough environments.

1. Choose the Right Rubber Material

Not all rubber is created equal. The first step to improving durability is matching the rubber compound to its operating environment. Common material choices include:

Material Key Strengths Common Applications
EPDM Excellent resistance to heat, ozone, and weathering Outdoor equipment, HVAC seals
Nitrile (Buna-N) Resists oil, fuel, and hydraulic fluid Pumps, compressors, oil seals
Silicone Performs well in extreme temperature ranges Food processing, aerospace
FKM (Viton) Resistant to chemicals, fuels, and high temperatures Chemical processing, automotive
Neoprene Versatile with good weather and abrasion resistance General-purpose gaskets and mounts

Selecting the right compound helps prevent swelling, cracking, or hardening over time — the leading causes of seal failure.

2. Optimize the Seal Design

Durability often comes down to design. A well-designed seal distributes stress evenly, maintains compression, and prevents leaks even under fluctuating pressures. Consider these key design principles:

  • Proper compression ratio: Too much compression causes stress and deformation; too little leads to leaks.
  • Smooth sealing surfaces: Sharp edges or uneven finishes increase wear.
  • Avoid thin cross-sections: Thin sections are prone to tearing and distortion.
  • Support against extrusion: In high-pressure applications, use backup rings or harder durometer rubbers.

Even small tweaks in geometry can add years of life to a seal.

3. Control Environmental Exposure

Heat, UV light, ozone, and chemicals all accelerate rubber degradation. Protect your seals by:

  • Shielding from direct sunlight when possible.
  • Choosing ozone-resistant materials like EPDM or silicone.
  • Using compatible lubricants — avoid petroleum-based greases with non-oil-resistant compounds.
  • Considering coatings or additives that enhance resistance to harsh environments.

These preventative measures are especially important for seals exposed to outdoor conditions or fluctuating temperatures.

4. Ensure Proper Installation and Compression

Many gasket failures occur not from bad materials, but from improper installation. Over-tightening bolts, using the wrong gasket thickness, or misaligning parts can crush or tear the seal before it ever goes into service. Always:

  • Use torque specifications recommended by the manufacturer.
  • Confirm uniform compression across the sealing surface.
  • Inspect for damage or contamination before assembly.

Taking the time to install correctly pays off with longer-lasting, more reliable performance.

5. Partner with an Experienced Rubber Manufacturer

Designing seals and gaskets that last requires more than just the right material — it takes experience. Working with a trusted manufacturer ensures your parts are engineered with the right durometer, compression set, and geometry for your specific environment.

Built for Durability — Built in the USA

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom rubber injection molding and precision gasket manufacturing. Our U.S.-based team uses high-quality materials and proven processes to create seals that perform under pressure — and keep performing for years to come.

Whether you need oil-resistant nitrile gaskets, high-temp silicone seals, or complex molded geometries, we can help you engineer parts that meet your exact requirements and last in the field.

Primo Rubber Co. — your trusted partner for durable, high-performance industrial rubber components. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn how to design longer-lasting industrial rubber seals and gaskets through better materials, design practices, and manufacturing methods.

entry.title: EPDM vs Nitrile vs Silicone: Which Rubber Material Should You Use?

link.title: EPDM vs Nitrile vs Silicone: Which Rubber Material Should You Use?

entry.content:
Choosing the right rubber compound is one of the most important steps in creating a reliable, high-performing molded part. Each material has its strengths and weaknesses depending on the environment, temperature, and chemical exposure. Among the most common options are EPDM, Nitrile (Buna-N), and Silicone. Here’s how they compare — and how to choose the right one for your application.

EPDM (Ethylene Propylene Diene Monomer)

EPDM is known for its excellent resistance to weathering, ozone, water, and UV exposure. It performs exceptionally well outdoors and in applications exposed to the elements. It also resists many polar substances, including alcohols, brake fluids, and phosphate esters.

Best For:

  • Outdoor seals and gaskets
  • HVAC components
  • Automotive weatherstripping
  • Water system parts and hoses

Limitations:

EPDM doesn’t handle petroleum oils or hydrocarbons well. For applications involving fuel, lubricants, or oil contact, another material (like Nitrile) is a better fit.

Nitrile (Buna-N)

Nitrile rubber is the go-to choice for oil-resistant applications. It has excellent resistance to fuels, lubricants, and many hydraulic fluids, making it a popular choice in industrial and automotive environments. It also offers good tensile strength and abrasion resistance.

Best For:

  • Fuel and oil seals
  • Industrial hoses and grommets
  • Automotive gaskets and O-rings
  • Hydraulic and pneumatic seals

Limitations:

Nitrile doesn’t perform as well in extreme weather or UV exposure. It can also stiffen in very cold temperatures, so outdoor flexibility can be an issue in freezing environments.

Silicone

Silicone rubber excels in temperature stability and flexibility across a wide range — typically from -75°F to +450°F. It’s also highly inert, non-reactive, and available in FDA-approved grades, making it a favorite in medical, food, and electronics applications. Silicone maintains softness and elasticity even under heat and compression.

Best For:

  • Food-grade and medical products
  • High-temperature seals and gaskets
  • Electronics and lighting components
  • Environments requiring chemical or ozone resistance

Limitations:

Silicone is not as strong as Nitrile or EPDM in tear or abrasion resistance, and it can be more costly. It’s also less resistant to fuels and oils.

Choosing the Right Rubber for Your Project

Selecting the right compound means understanding your environment:

  • Exposure to oil or fuel? → Go with Nitrile.
  • Outdoor or weather-exposed? → Choose EPDM.
  • High temperature or FDA compliance? → Silicone is ideal.

Each material has trade-offs, and the best choice often depends on balancing performance, durability, and cost.

Primo Rubber Co. Can Help You Choose the Perfect Material

At Primo Rubber Co., we work with a wide variety of rubber compounds — including EPDM, Nitrile, Silicone, and more — to ensure every part meets your performance requirements. Our experience in material selection and molding allows us to guide customers toward the best rubber for their unique application, from prototypes to full-scale production. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: A detailed comparison of EPDM, Nitrile (Buna-N), and Silicone rubber — their properties, strengths, and best use cases for molded parts.

entry.title: How Temperature, Chemicals, and UV Exposure Affect Rubber Longevity

link.title: How Temperature, Chemicals, and UV Exposure Affect Rubber Longevity

entry.content:
Rubber parts are often chosen for their flexibility and resilience, but even the toughest compounds degrade over time when exposed to extreme environments. Understanding how temperature, chemical exposure, and UV radiation affect rubber longevity can help you design parts that perform reliably for years instead of months.

Below, we’ll explore how each factor influences performance — and what you can do to extend the life of your rubber products.

Temperature: The Hidden Stress on Rubber

Temperature extremes are one of the biggest challenges in rubber performance. As heat increases, rubber can lose elasticity, soften, and even start to thermally degrade. In cold temperatures, it becomes brittle and prone to cracking.

Each rubber compound has its own service temperature range:

  • EPDM: Excellent at high temperatures (up to ~300°F) and resistant to heat aging.
  • Nitrile (Buna-N): Performs well in oils and fuels but has a lower upper limit (around 250°F).
  • Silicone: Exceptional thermal stability from -75°F to +450°F, ideal for extreme conditions.

Overheating or thermal cycling can also accelerate compression set, causing seals or gaskets to lose their ability to maintain pressure over time.

Chemicals: Attack from the Inside Out

Chemical exposure can break down rubber at the molecular level. Certain oils, fuels, and solvents can swell the rubber, while oxidizers or acids can cause it to harden or crack.

Here’s how common materials react:

  • Nitrile resists petroleum oils and fuels, making it perfect for automotive and industrial use.
  • EPDM is excellent against water, steam, and many polar chemicals but breaks down in oil-based fluids.
  • Fluoroelastomers (like Viton) are highly resistant to aggressive chemicals, but come at a higher cost.

If your part operates in contact with lubricants, cleaning agents, or process fluids, choosing the right compound is crucial to avoid swelling, softening, or embrittlement.

UV and Ozone: The Silent Degraders

Outdoor environments introduce another challenge: UV radiation and ozone. Both can cause surface cracking, discoloration, and loss of elasticity. These effects are often subtle at first but accelerate over time, especially in parts exposed to sunlight or electrical discharge.

  • EPDM offers excellent resistance to ozone and UV, making it ideal for outdoor use.
  • Silicone also performs well in sunlight and high-ozone environments.
  • Nitrile, however, tends to degrade quickly under UV exposure without protective additives or coatings.

To improve longevity outdoors, manufacturers often add anti-ozonants, stabilizers, or protective coatings to slow down surface degradation.

Designing for Longevity

To ensure your rubber parts last:

  1. Match the material to the environment. Consider temperature range, chemical exposure, and outdoor conditions.
  2. Avoid overstressing parts. Mechanical strain accelerates cracking and fatigue.
  3. Use protective finishes or housing designs that limit UV and ozone exposure.
  4. Work with an experienced manufacturer who understands how to balance material properties with real-world conditions.

Built to Last with Primo Rubber Co.

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in creating rubber components that stand up to challenging conditions — from high-temperature seals to outdoor gaskets and chemical-resistant parts. Our team helps you select the right compound for your specific environment, ensuring long-lasting performance and dependable quality in every part. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn how heat, chemical exposure, and UV light impact rubber durability — and how to choose materials that last longer in harsh environments.

entry.title: Designing Rubber Components for the Automotive Industry

link.title: Designing Rubber Components for the Automotive Industry

entry.content:
The automotive industry relies heavily on rubber components to ensure vehicles perform reliably and safely. From engine mounts to door seals, custom-molded rubber parts are essential to comfort, safety, and performance. But designing these components for modern vehicles requires more than just choosing a flexible material — it demands attention to temperature, chemical exposure, noise reduction, and manufacturability.

The Role of Rubber in Automotive Design

Rubber is used throughout vehicles to absorb vibration, seal out contaminants, and handle the stress of constant motion. Common automotive rubber parts include:

  • Weather seals around doors, trunks, and windows
  • Engine and transmission mounts that reduce vibration and noise
  • Bushings and grommets that cushion and isolate mechanical systems
  • O-rings and gaskets for fluid systems
  • Hoses and tubing for air, coolant, and fuel delivery

Each component has specific performance requirements depending on where it’s used.

Key Design Factors

1. Temperature Resistance

Rubber parts near engines, exhausts, or brakes must endure temperatures well above 100°C. Silicone and fluoroelastomers (FKM/Viton) perform exceptionally in high-heat environments, maintaining elasticity where standard rubbers would harden or crack.

2. Chemical Compatibility

Automotive fluids — oils, fuels, coolants, and brake fluids — can degrade standard rubber compounds. Nitrile (Buna-N) and EPDM are common choices for their strong resistance to oils and glycol-based fluids, respectively.

3. Noise, Vibration, and Harshness (NVH)

Reducing NVH is a major design priority for modern vehicles, especially electric ones. Rubber bushings, gaskets, and isolators are tuned for specific hardness (durometer) to balance stiffness with vibration absorption.

4. Tight Tolerances and Consistency

Automotive OEMs demand precise dimensions and repeatable quality. Rubber injection molding allows for high accuracy and consistent results across large production runs, ensuring every part fits perfectly on the assembly line.

Choosing the Right Material

Here’s a quick overview of popular rubber materials used in automotive parts:

Material Strengths Common Uses
EPDM Weather, ozone, and heat resistance Seals, hoses, and gaskets
Nitrile (Buna-N) Oil and fuel resistance Engine and transmission seals
Silicone High temperature and flexibility Engine bay components, EV cooling systems
Neoprene Vibration and weather resistance Mounts and isolators
Fluoroelastomer (Viton) Excellent heat and chemical resistance Fuel system seals, turbocharger hoses

Why Design for Injection Molding

Rubber injection molding is ideal for automotive applications because it enables tight tolerances, efficient production, and high repeatability. It’s also more suitable than compression molding for high-volume parts, as it reduces waste and shortens cycle times.

Partnering with an Experienced Manufacturer

Designing automotive rubber parts takes experience — not only in material science but also in tooling, molding, and testing. A trusted manufacturer can assist early in the design phase to optimize part geometry and material selection for the specific performance goals of your component.

Built for the Road Ahead

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom rubber injection molding for automotive and industrial applications. Our U.S.-based team works with a wide range of materials and can help you design and produce durable, high-performance parts that meet the demanding standards of the automotive industry. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: A guide to designing durable, high-performance rubber parts for cars, trucks, and EVs — from material selection to molding methods.

entry.title: Custom Rubber Parts for Agriculture Equipment — What to Know Before Ordering

link.title: Custom Rubber Parts for Agriculture Equipment — What to Know Before Ordering

entry.content:
Agricultural equipment operates in some of the harshest environments imaginable — extreme temperatures, constant vibration, exposure to sunlight, chemicals, and moisture. That’s why the rubber components used in tractors, sprayers, harvesters, and other machinery need to be built to last.

Whether you’re sourcing replacement seals or developing a new product line, understanding what to look for in custom rubber parts for agriculture can save you time, money, and maintenance headaches.

Common Rubber Parts Used in Agriculture Equipment

Rubber is used throughout agricultural machinery for flexibility, vibration isolation, and environmental protection. Some of the most common parts include:

  • Seals and gaskets for hydraulic systems and fuel tanks
  • Bushings and vibration isolators for engine and suspension mounts
  • Hoses and grommets for fluid and electrical routing
  • Protective boots and covers to guard against dust and debris
  • Weather seals for cabs, enclosures, and operator controls

Each of these components faces unique environmental stresses that affect material choice and design.

Key Design Considerations

When ordering custom rubber parts for farm or industrial equipment, it’s important to consider the full range of operating conditions.

1. Environmental Exposure

Agricultural parts must endure UV radiation, ozone, mud, fertilizers, and oils. Materials like EPDM perform well against weathering and ozone, while Nitrile (Buna-N) excels when exposed to oils and fuels.

2. Temperature Range

Machinery may run in freezing cold or under the summer sun for hours at a time. Select materials that can maintain flexibility and sealing ability across wide temperature ranges.

3. Durability and Tear Resistance

Rubber parts exposed to vibration, impact, and abrasion need excellent mechanical strength. Reinforced compounds or specialized formulations help extend service life.

4. Compatibility with Chemicals

Fertilizers, hydraulic fluids, and cleaning chemicals can degrade standard rubber over time. Always verify that your compound is chemically compatible with its working environment.

Material Recommendations

Here’s a quick guide to common rubber materials for agricultural applications:

Material Strengths Common Uses
EPDM Weather, ozone, and water resistance Outdoor seals, cab gaskets, water systems
Nitrile (Buna-N) Oil and fuel resistance Hydraulic seals, fuel hoses
Neoprene Good all-around performance Vibration isolators, grommets
Silicone Wide temperature range, UV stable Electrical seals, cab components

Partnering with the Right Manufacturer

The best results come from working with a manufacturer that understands both rubber molding and the unique demands of agricultural equipment. Custom tooling allows for tight tolerances, consistent fit, and repeatable performance across large production runs.

Built to Perform in the Field

At Primo Rubber Co., we produce custom-molded rubber parts designed to handle the rough conditions of agricultural work. Whether you need weatherproof seals, oil-resistant hoses, or vibration isolators, our U.S.-based team can help you choose the right material and deliver durable, high-quality parts built to perform season after season. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn what to consider when sourcing custom rubber parts for tractors, sprayers, and other agricultural equipment — from material choice to durability.
